text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
This transmits revised IRM 1.35.16, Financial Accounting, Managerial Cost Accounting.
IRM 1.35.16.1, Program Scope and Objectives - Updated text to comply with new writing style guide and made minor writing edits for clarity.
IRM 1.35.16.1.6, Deﬁnitions - Added deﬁnitions for corporate overhead rate, inter-entity costs, and intra-departmental costs.
IRM 1.35.16.1.9, Cost versus Budget - Updated to add references to Key budget tools and IRM 1.33.3, Reimbursable Operating Guidelines.
IRM 1.35.16.2, Cost Accounting Standards - Edited tittle and text to more accurately describe standards.
IRM 1.35.16.2.1, Requirement for Cost Accounting - Edited text for clarity.
IRM 1.35.16.2.2, Responsibility Segments - Edited text for clarity.
IRM 1.35.16.2.3.2, Indirect Costs - Edited text for clarity and consolidated text from 1.35.16.2.3.2.1, Agency Sustaining costs, and 1.35.16.2.3.2.2 Support Costs into this section.
1.35.16.2.3.2.2, Support Costs - Deleted and text added to IRM 1.35.16.2.3.2 (4).
Throughout IRM - Updated acronyms and formatting to comply with new writing guidance. Made minor writing edits for clarity.

) Purpose: To provide policies and procedures for cost recognition, managerial costing methods and reporting. (
) Audience: Business unit and ﬁnance staff (
) Policy Owner: CFO (
) Program Owner: Cost Accounting and User Fees office (
) Primary Stakeholders: Business units and IRS ﬁnance community (
) Program Goals: To ensure internal controls are implemented and assist offices in applying managerial cost accounting (MCA) policies. (
) The CFO Act of

requires agency officers to develop and maintain an inte- grated agency accounting and ﬁnancial management system, including ﬁnancial reporting and internal controls for reporting cost information. In October

, the Secretary of the Treasury, the director of the Office of Man- agement and Budget (OMB) and the Comptroller General established the Federal Accounting Standards Advisory Board (FASAB) by a memorandum of understanding (MOU). The FASAB is responsible for promulgating the govern- ment’s accounting standards. These standards are recognized as generally accepted accounting principles (GAAP) for the federal government. (
) In July
, FASAB issued Statement of Federal Financial Accounting Standards (SFFAS)
, Managerial Cost Accounting Standards and Concepts. This statement contains the concepts and standards for accumulating, calculat- ing and reporting internal cost data. (
) In April
, FASAB issued Statement of Federal Financial Accounting Concepts (SFFAC)
, Entity and Display, which describes the items that should be included in federal ﬁnancial reports. OMB Circular A-

, Financial Reporting Requirements, establishes federal ﬁnancial reporting guidance for executive branch departments, agencies and entities required to submit audited ﬁnancial statements, interim ﬁnancial reports and performance and ac- countability reports (PAR) or agency ﬁnancial reports (AFR). (
) In May
, FASAB issued SFFAS
, Amending Inter-Entity Cost Provisions. This statement revised Interpretation
, Accounting for Imputed Intra- Departmental Costs: An Interpretation of SFFAS
, and rescinded SFFAS
, Inter-Entity Cost Implementation. Revised SFFAS
provides for the continued recognition of signiﬁcant inter-entity costs by business-type activities. (

The Associate CFO for Financial Management and Deputy Associate CFO for Administrative Financial Management are responsible for:

Managing the MCA program and compliance with applicable authorities. Developing, communicating and updating MCA policies. Providing agency corporate overhead rate annually. Coordinating the development of MCA reporting with the business units and reviewing their costing allocation methods. Developing and maintaining cost

based performance measures. Overseeing the Cost Section operations, developing procedures for internal controls, segregation of duties, and documenting supervisory reviews. Managing jointly with the Financial Management Systems office the grated Financial System (IFS) cost accounting module, producing, reconciling and analyzing the statement of net cost (SNC).
Implementing and maintaining their managerial costing program.

Setting guidelines to identify direct labor and beneﬁts for application of the corporate overhead rate. Recording and reporting costs timely and properly in IFS. Implementing periodic reviews of cost accounting data in IFS for accuracy. Ensuring cost data aligns with current organizational structure, programs, projects and activities. Informing the Cost Accounting and User Fees office of organizational changes that may affect the IRS’s SNC. Reviewing secondary cost allocation methodologies with the Cost Ac- counting and User Fees office annually and obtaining approval from their management for signiﬁcant changes.

) Program effectiveness is measured monthly after assessment cycles are completed and cost and exchange revenue are fully allocated to the opera- tional divisions and classiﬁed to the four major IRS’s programs. (

) The following controls are in place to ensure proper MCA: a. Business units obtain the necessary level of approval and propose allo- cation methodology changes to the Cost Accounting and User Fees office. b. The Cost Accounting and User Fees office validates that allocation and organizational changes are accurately entered into IFS and reviews the results. c. Monthly reconciliations between the SNC and the trial balance are completed to verify that cost and exchange revenue allocations were suc- cessfully executed. d. Accountants use a password protected report that is reviewed and approved as a mechanism to control the monthly cost allocation process and ensure the accuracy of cycle execution. e. Separate roles and responsibilities are established for preparers, reviewers and approvers. f. Reports are saved on a shared-drive with access limited to users with appropriate job requirements. (

Allocation - A process that reassigns costs to cost centers that use resources from other cost centers that incurred the costs.

b. Assessment cycles - The order of execution in which certain costs are allocated to programs. Assignment cycles follow a step process and some cycles use the results of previous assessment cycles. c. Causal relationship - A connection between two activities where the cost of one activity changes or affects the cost of another activity. d. Corporate overhead rate - The rate calculated annually by the Cost Ac- counting and User Fees office and applied to directly identiﬁed labor and beneﬁts to determine the full cost of providing goods or services. e. Costs - The monetary value of resources used in performing activities, in acquiring or producing goods and services. f. Cost assignment - A process that associates costs with activities, products or services. Costs can be assigned to processes, programs and business units using direct tracing, cause-and-effect and allocation methods. g. Cost center - An IFS data element used to represent a clearly deﬁned location where costs are incurred. A cost center represents the lowest level in the organizational hierarchy and is usually linked to a Treasury Integrated Management Information System (TIMIS) code for labor expenses. Cost centers can also be established for non-labor expenses. h. Cost element - A classiﬁcation of the type of expense incurred. i. Cost driver - The basis used to allocate the costs of ﬁnancial resources. Examples of cost drivers include square footage, number of full-time equivalents (FTEs), service calls answered, tax cases closed and labor dollars. j. Cost-effectiveness - The economic beneﬁt of producing good results without spending a lot of ﬁnancial resources. k. Cost object - A product, service or activity where costs are accumulated or measured. A cost object can be a customer, product or a group of employees that beneﬁt from work activities. l. Direct costs - Costs incurred directly by programs due to their budget execution. These include salaries, beneﬁts, consulting, materials, supplies, etc. m. Efficiency - A performance measure that associates outputs to inputs and is often expressed by the output cost per unit. n. Fiscal year - A twelve-month period used by an organization for budgeting, accounting and ﬁnancial reporting. The federal government’s ﬁscal year begins on October
and ends on September

o. Full cost - All costs used in generating activities, products and services, including direct, indirect and imputed costs. p. Functional area - An IFS data element that represents an activity, such submission processing or ﬁeld examination. q. Imputed costs - Unreimbursed costs required to be recognized by ac- counting standards. r. Indirect costs - Costs of resources that are jointly or commonly used and cannot be reasonably identiﬁed and charged to a speciﬁc activity. s. Inter-entity costs - Cost of beneﬁts, goods and services received by the IRS from other federal agencies, bureaus or departments. t. Integrated Financial System (IFS) - The IRS’s administrative accounting system. IFS has four modules: budget control system (BCS), materials management (MM), ﬁnancial accounting (FI) and controlling (CO). u. ) The IRS uses cost information, as required by SFFAS

: Managerial Cost Ac- counting Standards and Concepts , to report the cost of activities, programs and services to internal and external stakeholders. It is also used in analyzing and evaluating operating performance, supporting decision-making when allo- cating resources and modifying programs. (
) MCA follows GAAP and records costs using the accrual method of accounting. (

) The IFS integrates several modules to collect ﬁnancial transactions. Cost data is recorded under the IFS CO module. Costs are recorded when expenses paid or accrued without regard to the ﬁscal year when the obligations, commit- ments and disbursements happened. The CO module also includes imputed costs, depreciation, amortization and costs allocated to programs using costing methods. (

) The CO module is used for: a. Preparing the SNC for the audited ﬁnancial statements. b. Reporting cost analysis of programs and services to report to internal management, Congress, Treasury, OMB, TIGTA and GAO. c. Reporting the cost of user fees and trust funds. d. Determining the corporate overhead rate. e. Calculating cost beneﬁt analyses and cost-based performance measures for products, services and activities. f. Reporting on savings from discontinuing programs or activities. (
) Budgetary accounting focuses on inputs and outlays for the year and expendi- tures are generally recorded using the cash method of accounting. (
) Funds management data for budgeting purposes is recorded in the FM module. The FM module contains obligations, commitments and disbursements

Funds management data for budgeting purposes is recorded in the FM module. The FM module contains obligations, commitments and disbursements

for the current budget period. It does not contain imputed costs, depreciation and amortization. The FM module also includes the unit cost rates (UCRs), the 3-Year Rolling Forecast (3YRF) and the status of available funds (SOAF). The budget expenditures are aligned by funding responsibilities.

) A responsibility segment represents a group of business unit functional areas responsible for providing a speciﬁc category of services to taxpayers. (

) The IRS’s responsibility segments are categorized by four main programs reported in the audited ﬁnancial statements’ SNC. a. Taxpayer Assistance and Education - Assists taxpayers with tax return preparation. b. Filing and Account Services - Provides resources and support to taxpayers for ﬁling returns, paying taxes, issuing refunds and maintaining accounts. c. Compliance - Administers compliance activities after a return is ﬁled to identify or correct possible errors or underpayments. d. Administration of Tax Credits Programs - Administers the Earned Income Tax Credit and other credit programs. (

) Cost segmentation is based on the business units’ ﬁnancial plans. For purpose of managing, allocating and reporting costs, the business units are organized under three major cost categories. a. Operational: Units that provide taxpayer assistance and education, and accounting service, and compliance activities, and that administer credit programs. These units CI, LB&I, SB/SE, TE/GE and W&I. b. Support: Top level units that mainly support operational units in providing goods and services to the public. These units are Appeals, Chief Counsel and TAS. c. Agency sustaining: Units that provide Servicewide products, services and activities. These units are FMSS, C&L, CFO, HCO, PGLD, IT, and Executive Leadership and Direction. (
) This standard requires the IRS to recognize the full costs, direct and indirect, of responsibly segments, products, services and activities. (
) Full cost reporting is required for managing and establishing reimbursable ac- tivities, implementing user fees, and developing internal reports and cost studies. (

) The Cost Accounting and User Fees office maintains a detailed ﬂow chart of the methodology used to allocate direct and indirect costs to responsibility segments. Refer to the Cycle Run-Order Methodology . (

Travel, relocation and training. d. Consulting. e. Enforcement expenses. f. Automated data processing (ADP) or IT.

) Costs for speciﬁc products and services are treated as direct costs when the cost can readily be identiﬁed. (
) Direct costs are recorded to general ledger accounts that correspond to budget and commitment line items. (

) Indirect costs are sustaining and support costs allocated to other business units. High-level costs allocated within operational and support units is also considered indirect costs. In general, indirect costs are resources used by or more business units, cross-functional or centralized processes and include: a. General management and administration b. Rent, security, utilities and maintenance c. Procurement and contracting d. Financial management and accounting e. Information technology f. Research, analytical and statistical g. Human resources and personnel (

) Agency sustaining costs represent the costs of centralized, servicewide op- erations provided by CFO, C&L, Executive Leadership and Direction, FMSS, HCO, IT, PGLD. a. Agency sustaining costs can either be directly assigned or allocated to other business units. b. When sustaining costs cannot directly be assigned, causal relationships are used to allocate costs. c. Causal relationships assign resource costs to the support business unit’s activities and services and then assign those costs to the operating units that consume the services. d. Sustaining costs are allocated to products and services using pro-rata allocations when establishing a causal relationship is not possible. e. Pro-rata allocations use cost drives including FTEs, square footage, on- rolls head counts or business unit direct costs. f. Business units can also group costs into pools with similar characteristics for cost allocations. g. ) This standard requires the IRS to recognize the full cost of services from federal agencies even when the IRS is not required to reimburse the other agency. (
) The Financial Reporting and Analysis office, in collaboration with the business units, works with other agencies to obtain the necessary information for the IRS to record imputed costs. (
) Business unit’s full cost includes the full cost of goods and services received from other federal agencies regardless of the source of funding. (
) The IRS records imputed costs using the ﬁnancial data provided by the providing the services or by reasonable estimates when data is not available. (
) The IRS recognizes intra-departmental and inter-entity costs. (
) Recognition of imputed costs is limited to identiﬁable; material amounts that are a reasonable integral or necessary part of the IRS’s products or services. Allocation (

) IFS cost assessment cycles allocate sustaining and support costs that have not been assigned by direct tracing methods. An assessment cycle run identi- ﬁes the type of expense, allocation method and cost drivers. The main assessment cycles are:
Rent, building costs, high level ﬁnance, and technology to all business units.
Shared services support and other agency sustaining costs to support and operational units.
Support costs to operational units.

) Calculating Cost Outside of the Cost Module (

) The Cost Accounting and User Fees office calculates the corporate overhead rate annually. The rate calculation is based on cost accounting data from latest audited statement of net cost and is calculated by dividing indirect by direct costs (
) When indirect costs are not identiﬁable in the Integrated Financial System (IFS), the overhead rate is applied to directly identiﬁed labor and beneﬁts to arrive at full cost.
) Cost Reporting (
) SFFAC

, Objectives of Federal Financial Reporting , states that information about operating performance, including the costs of programs and outputs outcomes achieved, is an essential element of ﬁnancial reports. MCA provides information for internal users, including ﬁnancial accounting, budgetary ac- counting, and operational/program management. MCA also provides informa- tion for external users, including ﬁnancial auditors, OMB, Treasury and Congress. See also IRM
, Cost versus Budget.
) Internal Users (
) Cost information communicated outside of the IRS must be reviewed by the Cost Accounting and User Fees office to ensure its accuracy and appropriate disclosures. (

) Internal cost reporting should be tailored speciﬁcally to meet management’s needs. The form and content of internal cost reports prepared for each business unit should provide full cost information to program managers. (

reports such as cost-based performance measurers, imputed costs should included in the report to arrive at full cost, but it should be footnoted as a closure. (

) The Enforcement Revenue Information System (ERIS) is the system of when using enforcement revenue as a factor in performing calculations and analyses. The Cost Accounting and User Fees office obtains the annual Enforcement Revenue Collected (TERC) ﬁle from Research, Applied Analytics & Statistics (RAAS) that includes revenue collection for major program ries. ERIS is the data source for the TERC ﬁle. (

) Custodial funds not related to the IRS appropriated budget or non-appropriated revenues are accounted for in IFS. However, the IRS excludes these funds from the SNC. These funds include the Highway Trust Fund, Health Insurance Reform Implementation Fund and the Judgment Fund. The Cost Accounting and User Fees office maintains a ﬁscal year listing of trust fund exclusions. (

) Cost-based performance measures, commonly referred to as cost studies, completed annually for the IRS’s major examination and collection enforcement programs in collaboration with frontline program management and RAAS. A cost study is a cost-beneﬁt analysis that is part of the IRS programs’ account- ing practices. (

) A cost-beneﬁt analysis considers only one program at a time and compares the monetary costs and beneﬁts (enforcement revenue) of a program. The outcome measures of the studies are collections/cost ratio, cost per dollar tax collected and cost per case worked by the program. (

) A cost-beneﬁt analysis will not determine if a program is having a signiﬁcant net effect on desired outcomes. Tax compliance or economic values, other than cost, must be analyzed in determining program efficiencies and policy choices. (
) The OMB Circular A-

, Financial Reporting Requirements, details require- ments on preparing the SNC. The circular requires that the IRS, and other federal agencies, strive to articulate efficiency and effectiveness by developing and reporting objective measures that indicate results achieved and relate major goals and objectives in their strategic plan to responsibility segments presented in the entity’s SNC. The process of cost allocation results in all being allocated to the business units. (
) During the compilation of the SNC, costs are summarized by cost center functional areas. Functional areas are assigned to the four core program reported on the SNC, as described in IRM
